t: Psalm 49
Misplaced Trust in Wealth
For the choir director. A psalm of the sons of Korah.
Hear*pn this, all you peoples; listen,*ln all who inhabit the world,
both*ln low and high, rich*ln and poor together.
My*ln mouth speaks wisdom; my*ln heart’s meditation brings understanding.
I*ln turn my ear to a proverb; I*ln explain my riddle with a lyre.
Why*pn should I fear in times of trouble? The*ln iniquity of my foes surrounds me.
They*ln trust in their wealth and*ln boast of their abundant riches.
Yet*ln these cannot redeem a person or*ln pay his ransom to God—
since*ln the price of redeeming him is too costly, one*ln should forever stop trying—
so*ln that he may live forever and*ln not see the Pit.
For*pn one can see that the wise die; the*ln foolish and stupid also pass away. Then*ln they leave their wealth to others.
Their*ln graves are their permanent homes, their*ln dwellings from generation to generation, though*ln they have named estates after themselves.
But*ln despite his assets, mankind will not last; he*ln is like the animals that perish.
This*pn is the way of those who are arrogant, and*ln of their followers, who*ln approve of their words. Selah*ig
Like*ln sheep they are headed for Sheol; Death*ln will shepherd them. The*ln upright will rule over them in the morning, and*ln their form will waste away in Sheol, far*ln from their lofty abode.
But*ln God will redeem me from*ln the power of Sheol, for*ln he will take me. Selah*ig
Do*pn not be afraid when a person gets rich, when*ln the wealth of his house increases.
For*ln when he dies, he will take nothing at all; his*ln wealth will not follow him down.
Though*ln he blesses himself during his lifetime — and*ln you are acclaimed when you do well for yourself—
he*ln will go to the generation of his ancestors; they*ln will never see the light.
Mankind,*ln with his assets but*ln without understanding, is*ln like the animals that perish.
